treatmentPlanText: Protect first. Rule out high risk stress fx via imaging, rule out RED-S, minorInjuryR major (0 pain), Multi-directional strength exercises during rehab. Remember address biomechanical factors and footwear (supershoes, Vibrams etc)

Presents as deep plantar pain, and pain on dorsiflexion. Protect first. Rule out high risk stress fx  via imaging, rule out RED-S, 0/10 pain, Multi-directional strength exercises during rehab. Remember address biomechanical factors and footwear (supershoes, Vibrams etc)

Presents as deep ankle pain, difficulty WB. Obtain throughout running hx. Protect first. Rule out high risk stress fx via imaging, rule out RED-S, 0/10 pain, Multi-directional strength exercises during rehab. Remember address biomechanical factors and footwear (supershoes, Vibrams etc)
Can they heel walk/jump? Low-risk fracture managed with activity modification and protected weight-bearing 6-8 weeks for return to run. Address biomechanics and impact moderation behaviors.
6-10 wks NWB, imaging + obtain WB clearance from MD, stregnthen other muscles ASAP (prox hip, knee, UL) , start with minorInjuryR major (0 pain)

Treadmill ax and impact moderation behaviors with cadence, soft running and avoiding overstriding. Run-walk intervals takes precedence over exercises. 0/10 pain. Runners will often push themselves through this so presentation is likely more severe and calcitrant. Explain that rolling, Graston do not help the actual periosteum. This may be due to a high foot-strike angle (similar to MTSS), and over striding. Practice minimizing stride length, running softly and having a smaller stack and drop on shoes, running drills and running frequency before increasing distance or speed. Identify the aggravating factors, load the muscle in isolation and expose muscle back to aggravating factors.

Detail run hx, fulcrum, palpation, hop. High risk stress fracture area urgent referral as there may be a completed tibial fracture if there is continued running, rule out RED-S, minorInjuryR major (0 pain), Multi-directional strength exercises in rehab, consult  sports RD.  Explain complications as clients often continue to run and compete despite pain.
Low risk stress fracture area, rule out RED-S, minorInjuryR major (0 pain), Multi-directional strength exercises in rehab, consult  sports RD

Pathology: Fracture of the patella, femur, tibia, fibula
treatmentPlanText: Ottawa Knee Rules, 6-10 wks NWB, imaging + obtain WB clearance from MD, stregnthen other muscles ASAP (prox hip, knee, UL) , start with minorInjuryR major (0 pain)

Remember the patella and anterior tibial are high-risk areas stress fracture requiring aggressive evaluation; nonweight-bearing immobilization. Please refer out as it may require surgical intervention. 8-12 weeks rehabilitation, strengthen adjacent limbs while NWB.

Hedge from runing hx and maybe hop test or fulcrum. Refer immediately (high risk of avascular necrosis and displacement) Need imaging (cannot identify between high risk tension and lower risk compression side) & consult sports MD to clear, rule out RED-S, Multi-directional strength exercises during rehab. Explain complications as clients often continue to run and compete despite pain.
Caution for AIIS apophyseal avulsion fractures in adolescents, ASIS more likely in adults. Caution for femoral head stress fracture
Rule out high risk stress fx, rule out RED-S, minorInjuryR major (0 pain), Multi-directional strength exercises

May initially present like a glute medius tendinopathy but may be more of a trochanteric bursa if compressing on that side via side lying or crossing legs aggravate symptoms.  Focus on minimizing provoking positions, abductor and external hip rotation exercises, promote cycling as cross training before gentle return to running. If no improvement MDs may suggest cortisone, explain risks and promote rehab over injections.
Pain on point palpation, maybe antalgic gait, general pubic pain. Considered low risk, may refer it no improvement in 8 weeks. Strengthen auxillary hip muscles.

Sacral stress fx are considered low risk however please refer immediately if there are neurological symptoms or severe pain. Rule out high risk stress fx, rule out RED-S, minorInjuryR major (0 pain), Multi-directional strength exercises

Typically presents as hip pain in child 4-8 years, limp, restricted abduction/internal rotation. Urgent referral to surgical consultation for containment. 0 pain if planning to start running and having impact sports again. Strengthen peripheral hip and lumbo-pelvic muscles.

Urgent referral if you are diagnosis initial complaint. Typically obsese adolescent with antalgic gait and restricted intneral rotation. Sports-Med Consult for Plan, Repeat Imaging, 0 pain, Exercises.

This is a tibial tubercle apophysitis. Typically pain with kneeling, deep squats. Protect then adapt 0 pain, focus on capacity instead of load as it is often difficult to maintain a healthy load management and social schedule for adolescents in school.  Referral only needed if avulsion suspected or refractory
Important to differentiate from calcaneal stress fracture, as fat tissue is highly innervated. Offloading with heel cups or taping to desensitize may help (unclear of management).
Palpation helps differentiate between tendinopathy, usually identify source of compression as it may often be a shoe or a terrain issue with too much dorisflexion.

Infrapatellar fat pad which is very sensitive to pain in quick extension ranges, may be preceded by trauma. Focus on quadriceps strengthening to assist with desensitization, biomechanics of patella tracking (?). Progress slowly, avoid compression exercises (open chain extension), Spanish squat and leg press (closed chain) may be less irritating.

Pathology: Bursa of the pre-patellar and supra-patellar spaces
treatmentPlanText: Avoid hopping and impact, and deep flexion squats. Try spanish squats, straight leg raise, decline squats. Promote cycling, progress with running drills before running

May be a directional issue on the camber for track athletes, hip adduction during running. Compression of bursae from both passive and active structures (vastus lateralis). Introduce trails on flat, before progressing to uphill and downhill. Speed can precede volume in this injury
Squeeze test of the toe box theoretically compresses as a  Intermetatarsal space → joint/capsular region
Activity modification avoiding forced plantarflexion; physical therapy for ankle mobility and strength; may require surgical debridement if refractory.

Impingement at posterior ankle joint. Posterior ankle pain with plantarflexion, os trigonum tenderness. Modify activities first to avoid irritating cartilage ie downhills, aggressive plantar flexion. Progress rehabilitation towards stability and dynamic in other planes of ROM.  Surgical and imaging referral if refractory to 3-6 months conservative care

Pathology: Patella, femur, tibial plateau and tubercle joint irritation/arthritis
treatmentPlanText: Avoid hopping and impact, and deep flexion squats. Try spanish squats, straight leg raise, decline squats. Promote cycling, progress with running drills before running. Swelling via swipe test may be an indicator of overloading the structures during a session.

Make sure to help client understand between age-related meniscal tears (horizontal, asymptomatic) vs traumatic (ie bucket handle radial, that are symptomatic). Thessaly's, and knee PROM helpful for ruling out, discuss hx to get idea to rule in. Do not hesistate to refer for Sports MD consult and imaging if symptoms do not improve in 2-3 weeks of treatment and locking-catching symptoms persist.
Avoid speed, build volume. Hip and knee loading exercises, ?taping. May require angle specific open chain for inferior or superior pole irritation

Blunt trauma or sudden increases in activity can cause plica inflammation, fibrosis, and subsequent impingement, leading to anteromedial knee pain particularly in adolescents. Unload and desensitize and then progress (?)
Monitor for swelling after activity and running. Caution for impact, and deep flexion. Progressive with loading of quads, hamstrings and hips
Monitor for swelling after activity and running. Caution for impact, and deep flexion. Progressive with loading of quads, hamstrings and hips
Synovial outpouching related to joint. Investigate root cause of cyst, and promote cycling to reduce swelling
Monitor for swelling after activity and running. Caution for impact, and deep flexion. Progressive with loading of quads, hamstrings and hips

FAI is joint-driven impingement (cam/ pincer) type. Look for Anterior hip/groin pain with flexion/internal rotation, positive impingement test. Progress with running and exercises that are symptom free and not within impingement positions. Referral for surgical/sport MD consult if activity-limiting symptoms despite PT. No strong relationship between FAI and hip-OA but avoid pain provoking movements if able. Un-warranted scoping may contribute to early OA.

Monitor for swelling after activity and running. Caution for impact, and deep flexion, internal rotation and adduction of hip. Progressive with loading of hip extensors, abductors, external rotators then progress into flexors, internal rotators, adductors.

Monitor for swelling after activity and running. Caution for impact, and deep flexion, internal rotation and adduction of hip. Progressive with loading of hip extensors, abductors, external rotators then progress into flexors, internal rotators, adductors.

Monitor for swelling after activity and running. Caution for impact, and deep flexion, internal rotation and adduction of hip. Progressive with loading of hip extensors, abductors, external rotators then progress into flexors, internal rotators, adductors.
Very painful palpation. Rule of Laslett's Cluster. Monitor during pregnancy and post-partum. Focus on core stabilizing exercises and progress them to functional exercises
Use Laslett's Cluster to Rule Out. Monitor during pregnancy and post-partum. Focus on core stabilizing exercises and progress them to functional exercises

Likely will need repeated imaging and re-assessment. Remember the affected Capsulo-Ligamentous Injury of Tarsal and Tarsal-metatarsal joints. Progress from static stability, to dynamic and plyometric stability. Query 6-8 weeks for progress?
Use splay test, or external rotation test to assess for pain, separation and correlate with instability ankle symptoms. Focus on ankle stability on unstable surfaces.
May require brace and follow up with Sports Med. Heals the fastest out of the 4 ligaments, assess if ACL or medial meniscus hurt as well. Knee stabilizing exercises of the vastus medialis.
Focus on hamstring and quadriceps strengthening exercises, progress to single leg proprioception and stability.

Unlikely to be an isolated cause of lateral knee pain but could be a factor as IT band may insert there. Taping may improve pain as a placebo? Decrease time on manual therapy. Focus on proprioception, balance

Pathology: Sacro-tuberous and iliac ligaments, labral injury
treatmentPlanText: Ensure single leg stability, and adductor muscles are strong enough to asborp impact forces. Practice running drills ABCs.

Pathology: Inguinal, superior and inferior pubic ligaments
treatmentPlanText: Ensure single leg stability, and adductor muscles are strong enough to asborp impact forces. Practice running drills ABCs.
Walk barefoot and progress to walk/run barefoot. Hop with toes up
Walk barefoot and progress to walk/run barefoot. Hop with toes up
Try reducing heel-to-ground angle; try forefoot strike then wean off with cadence improvements. Do not promote surgical fasciotomy as it will not resolve the underlying issues of biomechanics.

Try reducing heel-to-ground angle; try forefoot strike then wean off with cadence improvements. Load with banded exercises throughout dorisflexion range to improve tissue tolerance. Progress to uphill running slowly.
Try changing to forefoot strike, walk run intervals
Load muscle throughout entire ROM. Include both soleus and gastrocnemius variations to maximize stimulation of muscles. Progress with volume first before speed.
Rare running injuries, look for compression clothing that may be irritating muscles. External tibial rotation may be needed to load poplteus more (include in both heel slides and lunges)

Commonly occurs from sprinting, speedwork and hill workouts. Load initially in prone or seated with tibia internally rotated. Ensure to go through entire ROM. Progress slowly with volume first and then speed.
Rare running injury, look for compression clothing that may be irritating muscles. External tibial rotation may be needed to load poplteus more (include in both heel slides and lunges)

This may be due to a high foot-strike angle (similar to MTSS), and over striding. Practice minimizing stride length, running softly and having a smaller stack and drop on shoes, running drills and running frequency before increasing distance or speed. Identify the aggravating factors, load the muscle in isolation and expose muscle back to aggravating factors.

This may be due to downhill running, or track and field, but also a heavier and more stacked shoe if the ankle ends up supinating more than usual. Identify the aggravating factors, load the muscle in isolation and expose muscle back to aggravating factors.

Downhill running may often be culprit for these injures. Load the vastus lateralis in seated or supine position concentrically/eccentrically. Proceed with squats, lunges and progress most importantly to intervals of downhill running which is key to returning to baseline.

Bias feet medially + knee flexion to load the lateral soleus. May explore running with different arch supports initially to minimize symptoms, but progress to barefoot running and running drills to increase intrinsic foot muscle strength and lateral soleus tolerance

Bias feet medially + knee extension to load the lateral gastrocnemius May explore running with different arch supports initially to minimize symptoms, but progress to barefoot running and running drills to increase intrinsic foot muscle strength and lateral soleus tolerance

Pathology: Internal obliques, Transversus, Rectus Abdominis Strain
treatmentPlanText: Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting.

Gentle dynamic stretching to maintain ROM, load gently from distal to proximal range, concentric/eccentric while maintaining tension through out.  Banded knee extension/flexion, progress to squats, lunges, reverse nordics.

Pathology: Glute Minimus, Tensor Fascia Lata, Vastus Lateralis
treatmentPlanText: Progress from clamshell, hip abductions in standing, single leg loading and plyometrics
Progress from clamshell, hip abductions in standing, single leg loading and plyometrics

Pathology: Myofascial pain of gemelli, quadratus femoris
treatmentPlanText: Progress from clamshell, hip external rotation in standing, single leg loading and plyometrics
Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting.

Challenging injury to manage since the surface area is so large and is exposed in hip flexion/compression (sitting) and in hip extension (standing, walking, running). Exercises performed in prone or standing. May require sleeping in prone or side-lying and avoiding any symptomatic sitting until pain is tolerable. Load early and consistently throughout range.

Most frequent nerve entrapment; Morton's Neuroma. Compression of the interdigital nerves usually between the 3rd and 4th toes, confirm with squeeze test. Examine shoe to see if the toe box or toe-off in running is a culprit. Hallux valgus or a hypermobile 1st MTP may form calluses leading to a more narrow toe box and compression. Decrease dorsiflexion, increase forefoot and interdigital mobility, try wider shoes.

Rare entrapment- SN is formed by the tibial and common peroneal nerve but may mimic gastrocnemius pain but tends to radiate past lateral malleolis and the 5th MTP. Identify compressing factors and perform sural nerve glides (sciatic glide but with plantar flexion, toe flexion and ankle inversion)

Typically burning , cramping and tingling on the medial ankle. Relief at night and with rest. Ensure proximal sciatic nerve is not irritated. Sustained passive foot eversion and FH dorisflexion for diagnosis or Tinel's. Modify footwear according to symptoms, heel lift if pain in dorisflexion or medial arch if in pronation. Identify provocations in running assessment and remove compression.  MCN may arrive from a LPN or a bifurcation

Hx of chronic ankle sprains and muscle herniations is a risk factor. Confirm with dorsiflexion + eversion + Tinel's. Pain is usually a diffuse ache over the sinus tarsi. Rehab on ankle instability, proprioception, modify footwear if needed and promote nerve glides.

Entrapment may occur on the EHL and the extensor retinaculum, or osteophytes and it presents itself as an ache in the 1st web space. Rule out compartment syndrome. Footwear changes to avoid direct pressure. Try to reduce footstrike angle, hills. May require prolonged walk run intervals and sports med referal.

Usually only the 1st branch LPN and it ends up on the quadratus plantae and abductor hallucis. Pain along the 4th and 5th toes. Pronation tends to irritate it during running. Important to differentiate from plantar fasciopathy as the pain is superior to the aponeurosis oprigin. Heel cups are helpful, ankle stability exercises are important as well as barefoot drills and running.

Pain along the medial heel and longitudinal arch, but more central. Entrapment occurs at abductor hallucis or FHL either internally by hypertrophy of the muscle or external compression via footwear. Branches of this nerve will branch out to 1st-3rd web spaces. Hallucis rigidis may be a factor to MPN pain as well. Desensitize tissue via modifying shoe or orthotics and increasing ankle stability, or improving running mechanics.

Pathology: Infrapatellar branch of the saphenous nerve
treatmentPlanText: Innervates the medial patella from the saphenous nerve. Try finding it from a prone position of hip extension, abduction, external rotation and some knee flexion to compress the branch on the medial patella

Confirm with hip extension, abduction, external rotation, knee extension and then ankle dorsiflexion and foot eversion. The largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is purely sensory. Pain may sometimes mimic tibial stress fracture, or aggravated by a pes anserine bursa. Any strength or motor deficits should rule out this diagnosis. Most exposed in the Hunter adductor canal coursing the sartorius.
Rare nerve injury. Confirm with hip extension, knee flexion and then hip adduction. Are there gait changes that can address this nerve injury?

Most common lateral nerve injury in runners but is self limiting. Avoid running downhill, or a combination of plantarflexion and inversion if symptomatic. If there is concern of axonal damage with footdrop, TENs may be appropriate

May mimic a sports hernia, but is distinguised by sharp border pain along the ASIS. May require a surgical consultation if anatomical variations are making it susceptible for entrapment and conservative treatment is not working
Repeated hip flexion during hills may be an aggravating factor. Use prone knee bend test as a way of "flossing/desensitizing" the nerve. Identify other factors that may be entraping the nerve
Rare injuries, not much known from the literature. Identify factors that are causing compression of the nerve. Increase mobility of joints around the affected area and gradually reintroduce loading.
Rare injuries, not much known from the literature. Identify factors that are causing compression of the nerve. Increase mobility of joints around the affected area and gradually reintroduce loading.
May occur from pregnancy, belt or phone band. Identify factors that are causing compression of the nerve. Increase mobility of joints around the affected area and gradually reintroduce loading.
Rare injuries, not much known from the literature. Identify factors that are causing compression of the nerve. Increase mobility of joints around the affected area and gradually reintroduce loading.
Rare nerve injury. Confirm with hip extension, knee flexion and then hip abduction. Are there gait changes or compressive clothing that can address this nerve injury?
Rare injuries, not much known from the literature. Identify factors that are causing compression of the nerve. Increase mobility of joints around the affected area and gradually reintroduce loading.
Rare injuries, not much known from the literature. Identify factors that are causing compression of the nerve. Increase mobility of joints around the affected area and gradually reintroduce loading.

Pathology: Ilioinguinal adhesions leading to ilioguinal & iliohypogastric nerve entrapment
treatmentPlanText: Identify factors that are causing compression of the nerve such as repetition and high intra-abdominal pressure. Will require activity modification and maybe surgical consultation if walk-run program does not improve
Rare injuries, not much known from the literature. Identify factors that are causing compression of the nerve. Increase mobility of joints around the affected area and gradually reintroduce loading.

Worsened by hip extension, lumbar extension and rotation, and over-striding. Iliopsoas can also compress the nerve. Avoid uphills, and overstriding. Try running drills, flexion-biased exercises and progress slowly in RTR program.
Rare injuries, not much known from the literature. Identify factors that are causing compression of the nerve. Increase mobility of joints around the affected area and gradually reintroduce loading.

Pathology: Posterior/Lateral cutaneous nerves of the thigh
treatmentPlanText: Rare injuries, not much known from the literature. Identify factors that are causing compression of the nerve. Increase mobility of joints around the affected area and gradually reintroduce loading.
Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting initially
Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting initially
Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting initially

Pathology: Referred pain from L4/L5 nerve roots
treatmentPlanText: Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting initially
Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting initially
Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting initially
Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting initially
Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting initially
Unclear, refer to sports med if spinal and core exercises are not improving.
Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting initially

Identify factors such as too tight or a shoe tongue, toe box or downhill running. Increase mobility of forefoot and MTPs, load the tendons. Progress to B skips (clawing toes back) and emphasize running downhill, try with barefeet. Address the edema that can cause compression in a trail race over time

Pathology: Tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis digitorum longus/brevis (tendons)
treatmentPlanText: Reduce compression of footwear, eccentric compression of downhill, progressive loading exercises

Many runners will want to protect the foot with thicker shoes instead of progressively loading it due to pain. Emphasize on barefoot walking, barefoot drills and running. Calf raises do not significantly load plantar fascia. Rare case for the shockwave machine to desensitize, but this can be substituted with a lacross ball.

Pathology: Tendinopathy (Flexor Digitorum Longus, Fibularis Longus, Abductor Hallucis Longus, Abductor Digiti Minimi)
treatmentPlanText: Reduce compression of footwear, eccentric compression of downhill, progressive loading exercises

Insertional is usually eccentric compression of uphill, and speedwork. Remove aggravating factors, load and then re-integrate aggravating factors back in. Progress with A skips, then plyometrics, then frequent small runs before speedwork. High likelihood of recurrence as runners will self-discharge earlier than time-frame of tissue healing

Pathology: Tendinopathy (Flexor Digitorum/Hallucis Longus, Fibularis Longus/Brevis, Tibialis Posterior)
treatmentPlanText: Reduce compression of footwear, eccentric compression of downhill, progressive loading exercises

Focus on flexor hallucis, calf raises with medial ankle rotation, progress to barefoot hopping with toes up, and barefoot running drills, and treadmill. Assess shoe or other aggravating the toes in extension.

Pathology: Tendons (Tib Ant, Ext D, Extensor Hallucis Longus)
treatmentPlanText: Reduce compression of footwear, eccentric compression of downhill, progressive loading exercises

Pathology: Tendons (Tib Post, Flex Dig, Flex Hallucis Longus)
treatmentPlanText: Reduce compression of footwear, eccentric compression of downhill, progressive loading exercises. Assess if shoe is promoting painful foot pronation where a medial arch support or changing camber angles could help.
Rare in runners but may occur in more hill workouts. Remove hills initially, load the quadricep tendon above 90 degrees of squatting position and then back into deep squat and then hills.

Downhill running may be an aggravating factor Careful or speedwork and plyometrics. Focus on 60 degree knee extension, and improving hamstring strength. Focus on volume before speed and downhill running. Downhill running will be prophylatic long term
Tendinous insertion group- Reduce compression of footwear, eccentric compression of downhill, progressive loading exercises
Hamstring tendinous structures- Reduce compression of footwear, eccentric compression of downhill, progressive loading exercises

Exercises may only be helpful for desensitizing tissue (little robust research to support), focus much more on walk run, speed internvals, multidirection. Avoid downhill and long distances (0/10 pain). Fascial/tendinous ITB structure
Hills may be an issue, progress back with them slowly. Try loading hip flexors in supine first, before standing. Load eccentrically as well, try A-skips before running again.
Load in adduction, progress Copenhagen. Query gait changes for scissor gait?
Load in hip extension, abduction heavily and progress to plyometrics. Start with volume first, avoid overstriding increase cadence before speed if possible. Running drills would be helpful.

May be a directional issue on the camber for track athletes, hip adduction during running. Compression of fascia from both passive and active structures (glute med/min/TFL). Introduce trails on flat, before progressing to uphill and downhill. Speed can precede volume in this injury.

May be a directional issue on the camber for track athletes, hip adduction during running. Compression of bursae from both passive and active structures (vastus lateralis). Introduce trails on flat, before progressing to uphill and downhill. Speed can precede volume in this injury
Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting initially
Load in adduction, progress Copenhagen. Query gait changes for scissor gait?
Diaphragmatic breathing, deadbug, single glute bridges, bridge on ball. Avoid sit-ups, crunches, bicycle crunches, heavy lifting initially

Avoid activities that compress the insertional tendon in deep hip flexion: hill sprints, deep squats, lunges, RDLs, downward dog stretch, touching-toes stretch, kettlebell swings. Load distally first and then progress back into deeper hip flexion ranges.

Out of scope. You can probably perform an ankle-brachial index test on a treadmill until symptomatic and record the pre-post blood pressures. Refer to Sports Med who will refer to vascular. If surgery is indeed not an option, reduce intensity build volume. Reorienting client goals is important to preserve limb integrity and quality of life.

Out of scope. You can probably perform an ankle-brachial index test on a treadmill until symptomatic and record the pre-post blood pressures. Refer to Sports Med who will refer to vascular. If surgery is indeed not an option, reduce intensity build volume. Reorienting client goals is important to preserve limb integrity and quality of life.

Refer to Sports Med who will refer to vascular. If surgery is indeed not an option, reduce intensity build volume. Reorienting client goals is important to preserve limb integrity and quality of life.

Reorienting client goals is important to preserve limb integrity and quality of life.

Reorienting client goals is important to preserve limb integrity and quality of life.
